description:
Eleginops maclovinus, commonly known as the Patagonian blennie or Falkland Island blennie, is a species of marine fish belonging to the family Eleginopsidae. It is found in the coastal waters of southern South America, including the Falkland Islands, Tierra del Fuego, and parts of Argentina and Chile.

Eleginops maclovinus is a small, elongated fish with a rounded snout and a single, continuous dorsal fin. It typically ranges in length from 20 to 40 centimeters. The fish has a dark brown or olive-green coloration on its back, with a lighter, often yellowish, belly. It has a large, terminal mouth with small, conical teeth and a well-developed, curved lateral line.

This species is known to inhabit rocky and kelp-dominated coastal habitats, often in areas with strong currents or wave action. It feeds primarily on small crustaceans, mollusks, and other invertebrates found in its environment. Eleginops maclovinus is an important component of the coastal ecosystem and serves as a prey item for larger predatory fish, seabirds, and marine mammals.

The Patagonian blennie is of commercial and recreational importance in its native range, where it is targeted by both commercial and artisanal fisheries. Its conservation status is currently evaluated as Least Concern by the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN).
